captions.text:
When I was in fourth grade,
my teacher said to us one day:

"There are as many even numbers
as there are numbers."
"Really?", I thought.

Well, yeah, there are
infinitely many of both,

so I suppose there are
the same number of them.

But even numbers are only part
of the whole numbers,
all the odd numbers are left over,

so there's got to be more whole numbers
than even numbers, right?
To see what my teacher was getting at,

let's first think about what it means
for two sets to be the same size.

What do I mean when I say
I have the same number of fingers
on my right hand as I do on left hand?

Of course, I have five fingers on each,
but it's actually simpler than that.

I don't have to count, I only need to see
that I can match them up, one to one.
In fact, we think that some ancient people

who spoke languages that didn't have words
for numbers greater than three
used this sort of magic.

For instance, if you let
your sheep out of a pen to graze,

you can keep track of how many went out
by setting aside a stone for each one,

and putting those stones back
one by one when the sheep return,

so you know if any are missing
without really counting.

As another example of matching being
more fundamental than counting,
if I'm speaking to a packed auditorium,

where every seat is taken
and no one is standing,

I know that there are the same number
of chairs as people in the audience,

even though I don't know
how many there are of either.

So, what we really mean when we say
that two sets are the same size
is that the elements in those sets
can be matched up one by one in some way.
My fourth grade teacher showed us

the whole numbers laid out in a row,
and below each we have its double.

As you can see, the bottom row
contains all the even numbers,
and we have a one-to-one match.

That is, there are as many
even numbers as there are numbers.
But what still bothers us is our distress

over the fact that even numbers
seem to be only part of the whole numbers.
But does this convince you

that I don't have
the same number of fingers
on my right hand as I do on my left?
Of course not.
It doesn't matter if you try to match

the elements in some way
and it doesn't work,
that doesn't convince us of anything.
If you can find one way

in which the elements
of two sets do match up,

then we say those two sets have
the same number of elements.
Can you make a list of all the fractions?

This might be hard,
there are a lot of fractions!
And it's not obvious what to put first,

or how to be sure
all of them are on the list.
Nevertheless, there is a very clever way

that we can make a list
of all the fractions.

This was first done by Georg Cantor,
in the late eighteen hundreds.

First, we put all
the fractions into a grid.
They're all there.
For instance, you can find, say, 117/243,
in the 117th row and 223rd column.
Now we make a list out of this

by starting at the upper left
and sweeping back and forth diagonally,
skipping over any fraction, like 2/2,

that represents the same number
as one the we've already picked.
We get a list of all the fractions,

which means we've created
a one-to-one match

between the whole numbers
and the fractions,

despite the fact that we thought
maybe there ought to be more fractions.

OK, here's where it gets
really interesting.
You may know that not all real numbers

-- that is, not all the numbers
on a number line -- are fractions.

The square root
of two and pi, for instance.
Any number like this is called irrational.
Not because it's crazy, or anything,

but because the fractions are
ratios of whole numbers,
and so are called rationals;

meaning the rest are
non-rational, that is, irrational.

Irrationals are represented
by infinite, non-repeating decimals.
So, can we make a one-to-one match

between the whole numbers
and the set of all the decimals,
both the rationals and the irrationals?

That is, can we make
a list of all the decimal numbers?
Candor showed that you can't.

Not merely that we don't know how,
but that it can't be done.

Look, suppose you claim you have made
a list of all the decimals.

I'm going to show you
that you didn't succeed,

by producing a decimal
that is not on your list.

I'll construct my decimal
one place at a time.
For the first decimal place of my number,

I'll look at the first decimal place
of your first number.
If it's a one, I'll make mine a two;
otherwise I'll make mine a one.
For the second place of my number,

I'll look at the second place
of your second number.

Again, if yours is a one,
I'll make mine a two,
and otherwise I'll make mine a one.
See how this is going?

The decimal I've produced
can't be on your list.
Why? Could it be, say, your 143rd number?
No, because the 143rd place of my decimal

is different from the 143rd place
of your 143rd number.
I made it that way.
Your list is incomplete.
It doesn't contain my decimal number.

And, no matter what list you give me,
I can do the same thing,

and produce a decimal
that's not on that list.

So we're faced with this
astounding conclusion:

The decimal numbers
cannot be put on a list.

They represent a bigger infinity
that the infinity of whole numbers.

So, even though we're familiar
with only a few irrationals,
like square root of two and pi,
the infinity of irrationals

is actually greater
than the infinity of fractions.
Someone once said that the rationals

-- the fractions -- are
like the stars in the night sky.
The irrationals are like the blackness.

Cantor also showed that,
for any infinite set,

forming a new set made of
all the subsets of the original set

represents a bigger infinity
than that original set.

This means that,
once you have one infinity,
you can always make a bigger one

by making the set of all subsets
of that first set.
And then an even bigger one

by making the set
of all the subsets of that one.
And so on.

And so, there are an infinite number
of infinities of different sizes.

If these ideas make you
uncomfortable, you are not alone.

Some of the greatest
mathematicians of Cantor's day
were very upset with this stuff.

They tried to make this different
infinities irrelevant,

to make mathematics work
without them somehow.
Cantor was even vilified personally,

and it got so bad for him
that he suffered severe depression,

and spent the last half of his life
in and out of mental institutions.
But eventually, his ideas won out.

Today, they're considered
fundamental and magnificent.

All research mathematicians
accept these ideas,
every college math major learns them,

and I've explained them
to you in a few minutes.

Some day, perhaps,
they'll be common knowledge.
There's more.

We just pointed out
that the set of decimal numbers

-- that is, the real numbers --
is a bigger infinity
than the set of whole numbers.

Candor wondered
whether there are infinities

of different sizes
between these two infinities.

He didn't believe there were,
but couldn't prove it.

Candor's conjecture became known
as the continuum hypothesis.

In 1900, the great
mathematician David Hilbert
listed the continuum hypothesis

as the most important
unsolved problem in mathematics.

The 20th century saw
a resolution of this problem,

but in a completely unexpected,
paradigm-shattering way.
In the 1920s, Kurt Gödel showed

that you can never prove
that the continuum hypothesis is false.
Then, in the 1960s, Paul J. Cohen showed

that you can never prove
that the continuum hypothesis is true.
Taken together, these results mean

that there are unanswerable
questions in mathematics.
A very stunning conclusion.

Mathematics is rightly considered
the pinnacle of human reasoning,

but we now know that even mathematics
has its limitations.

Still, mathematics has some truly
amazing things for us to think about.

title: How big is infinity? - Dennis Wildfogel

Actually, Cohen proved that the continuum hypothesis is independent of ZFC 
axioms. So smn could find axioms that we agree with, and such that the 
continuum hypothesis is true.﻿

I think the reason why no-one knows the length of infinity is because it is 
a nondeterministic polynomial number, there is no method telling us when 
we've will reached the end of infinity (Checking every number possible 
against every number possible, till we can no longer create any new 
floating point numbers. In theory if there are no new numbers wouldn't that 
be infinity?.. if at the end of infinity, it would loop on the final number 
forever looking for a new number).﻿

comments.text:
I've watched the video about the infinite hotel and was made aware that 
there are infinities of different sizes relative to each other. But I'm 
this video something confuses me. Shouldn't the set of whole numbers be 
bigger than the set of odd numbers, or the set of even numbers or the set 
of prime numbers and so on? Because even though you can match every even 
(odd or prime etc.) number side by side to a whole number you will always 
have a surplus of whole numbers unmatched. Am I wrong in this assumption 
and if yes why am I wrong?﻿

comments.author: MrDustinmcphate

comments.text:
+MrDustinmcphate​ So then the same would be with prime numbers as well, 
right?﻿ Only we don't have a function that can generate prime numbers. But 
if we did it would be the same and someone would probably win a Fields

comments.author: Boris Svetiev

comments.text:
+Boris Svetiev You are wrong because you can not think about infinity the 
same way you do a finite set. You will never have "a surplus of whole 
numbers" because you will never stop matching them up. That's the thing 
about infinity it never ends so we can't just look at the sets and see that 
they match up. In order to prove mathematically that two sets have the same 
size you have to come up with some way to match the elements up. Then if 
you can prove that no matter what element from one set you pick you have an 
element in the other set that matches up with it then we can say that the 
two sets have the same number of elements. In the case of the even numbers 
and the whole numbers it is the function f(x)=2x. No matter what whole 
number you give me I can plug it in to this function and match it up with 
an even number. And no matter what even number you give me I can divide it 
in half and get the whole number associated with it. And even though we 
can't actually sit here and match them all up we can still show that this 
function would work if we actually could. Therefore we say that they have 
the same number of elements.
comments.author: MrDustinmcphate

comments.author: Satish Subramanian

comments.text:
I find this argument to only be true because you are creating rules to 
measure infinity. There cannot be more decimal numbers than whole numbers, 
because neither has an end. Matching is a rule you made to try and 
understand infinite. But it is leading you astray. There are not as many 
even numbers as there are whole numbers, because they have no end, thus 
your explanation suggests there are no odd numbers. This reminds me of the 
stupid "paradox" about the foot race where they can only move half the 
distance to the goal. It is not really mind blowing, but rather a simple 
set of rules that contradict the goal. I could say what if two racers were 
not allowed to cross the finish line, do they race forever? No. In neither 
case is anyone racing, because the rules applied made it impossible to 
race. I am not sure why infinite is so hard to grasp, but you try and 
contain infinite to understand it. This is misleading and detrimental to 
understanding infinite. It cannot be contained, limits destroy infinite. ﻿
comments.author: Paul Nowlin

comments.text:
+john harbinger Your interpretation of negative number arithmetic as 
obvious because they're something we use every day and that they're just a 
product of our senses doesn't match up well with history.

The Greeks considered equations with negative solutions absurd. Europeans 
didn't actually even consider negative numbers to be numbers until Leibniz 
in the seventeenth century. I don't think that our senses or ability to 
perceive changed since then, only our education and mathematical 
developments.
comments.author: mach a

comments.text:
I don't think I agree with this. As I see it mathematics use numbers. 
Numbers did not come from arbitrary axioms, but from the way our senses 
work and what they perceive. This is the first use of numbers. Any 
deductive reasoning came after this. So multiplication is not done because 
mathematicians came up with rules. Do you want proof? Anybody can do 
multiplication without being a mathematician or know anything about the 
rules of mathematics.
comments.author: john harbinger

comments.text:
+john harbinger The fact that we can see justification that -3 * 2 = -6 in 
the everyday world is just evidence that the rules we use model the world 
well.

Math is based on deductive, not inductive, reasoning.  Deductive reasoning 
is where we establish rules and prove what follows based on those rules.

Inductive rules is where we observe patterns, and then try to come up with 
rules which describe those patterns.

Your method is an inductive one.  We see -3 * 2 = -6 in the world all 
around us, so it must be true.  But this is not a mathematical way of 
thinking.

In order to actually prove anything (which is what mathematics is about), 
we must establish rules which guide everything we do.

Yes, the multiplication of integers is governed by the construction of the 
integers, which is governed by the arithmetic of the natural numbers, which 
is governed by the Peano axioms.
comments.author: MuffinsAPlenty

comments.text:
+MuffinsAPlenty
You do not need rules to multiply numbers. -3*2 =-6 is something that you 
see in your everyday world. It is obvious why this above equation is 
correct.
comments.author: john harbinger

comments.text:
+15kwakmatthew Mathematicians are fine with people studying any axiom set 
they want, provided that the axiom set in consistent.  In that aspect, 
mathematics could be considered arbitrary.

However, once you have selected an axiom set to work with, it is absolutely 
not arbitrary.  And often times, the axiom set is not chosen arbitrarily 
(although it could be, if you wanted to).
comments.author: MuffinsAPlenty

comments.text:
+MuffinsAPlenty what I mean by arbitrary is: "determined by chance, whim, 
or impulse, and not by necessity, reason, or principle."
comments.author: 15kwakmatthew

comments.text:
+15kwakmatthew It depends on what you mean by arbitrary.

If we accept the axioms of ZFC (a type of set theory), then the results we 
have are, indeed, absolute based on this particular system.

However, you can change the axioms, and by changing the axioms, you can 
make different absolutes be true.

We generally use ZFC because it seems mostly true and useful to our 
physical universe and minds, but we could study different axioms and make 
up different rules if we so desired.
comments.author: MuffinsAPlenty

comments.text: +MuffinsAPlenty so math is not absolute, but arbitrary?
comments.author: 15kwakmatthew

comments.text:
"I find this argument to only be true because you are creating rules to 
measure infinity."

Congratulations.  You now know the biggest "secret" of mathematics. 
 Everything a mathematician shows is true is because he or she has created 
rules which allow it to be true.

So, yes, the only reason mathematicians can compare infinite sets is 
because they've come up with a method by which to compare infinite sets 
which produces different results given different infinite sets.

But that's the same with multiplying two numbers. -3 * 2 = -6 only because 
mathematicians came up with rules that allow us to multiply numbers.
comments.author: MuffinsAPlenty

comments.text:
I asked this question on a paradox site but wasn't sure if it was indeed a 
paradox and also wondered if it is somehow related to Pi. I was advised to 
ask on a mathematical infinity site.

A window cleaner has to clean the windows of an infinitely high building, 
to do this he has an infinitely extendable ladder, which he places 6 feet 
away from the bottom of the building. The higher the window cleaner gets, 
the more he's extended the ladder, the more he extends the ladder, the 
closer he constantly gets to 90 degrees- but due to the base always being 6 
feet away from the top of the ladder this is unachievable...
There's no doubt a simple answer to this- it's just been bugging me for 
years and every maths teacher I've asked didn't seem to have a clue what 
the hell I was talking about. Whoever can explain it gets an infinite 
amount of cash- kept safely on top of said building- I'll get the ladder 
ready... ;)﻿
comments.author: squarepants49

comments.text:
Thanks for your replies Fabian Kester & Jakub Pekárek, they've helped clear 
things up for me. I'm a mathematical illiterate so never looked into it too 
deeply- I thought there may have been a connection with Pi- a constant. I 
suppose if you take away the "infinity" and replace it with, "very very 
very high, lol, there is a constant as it's simply a right angled triangle, 
so the square of the hypotenuse (the ladder) is equal to the square of the 
two remaining sides (the building's height & the distance away from the 
building the ladder is placed). Thanks again. :)
comments.author: squarepants49

comments.text:
It is not a paradox. The problem here is that some concepts we see as 
different do merge when faced with infinity. The angle will be smaller than 
90° at any point but when considering infinity as well, it is smaller or 
equal to 90°. It is like the 0.999... number. No matter how many nines you 
have, it is still smaller than 1. However if you have infinate number of 
nines, it sort of becames 1, because their difference is 0.000... so there 
is no difference at all. Technically it means that you can't show these two 
to be different. And since they behave absolutely the same no matter what 
test you put them through, why say they are different at all? By definition 
they are identical (having identical properties). Same with your angle, it 
will always differ from 90°, but at infinity this difference will be 
0,00... which is not really different. So when you say it can never get 
there, it can (at infinity, supposing you can get to infonity in first 
place),, it just doesn't seem to be quite there to us. 
I am a mathematician myself, so I can only hope my explanation makes as 
much sence to you as it does to me :) enjoy
comments.author: Jakub Pekárek

comments.text:
+squarepants49
I'm no mathematician myself but maybe I can answer one or two of your 
questions. (1) I think it's no paradox because the ladder gets to 90 
degrees in infinity. Your misconception lies in the "can never get there". 
Ever getting there would mean a real length of the ladder but infinity is 
no real number. (2) The difference between your example with the ladder and 
getting from A to B is that there is a finite length between A and B but 
for the ladder to stand up at 90 degrees the ladder has to be infinitely 
extended.
comments.author: Fabian Kester

comments.author: yaiba2811

comments.text:
+UfoFrilla Actually it's really easy: infinity is not a measurment of size, 
it's an idea, and that's why regular laws of math don't affect it (you can 
read a little about it's usage in infinitesimal calculus and set theory - 
which are entirely different, but in their fundemental concepts are very 
similar).
Since infinity is not a measurement of size, quantity or length, when we 
say one infinity is "bigger" than the other, we do not mean it is bigger in 
size, but bigger in the way that WE grasp it. The claim that the real 
numbers' infinity is greater than the rationals' comes from the idea that 
you can find a method to count all the rationals in the world (even if not 
in practice, then in theory) - but you cannot find any method to count all 
the REAL numbers, not even in theory - and that's what Cantor has proven 
using the method shown in this video (called Cantor's diagonal argument).
comments.author: Roy Sommer

comments.text:
+Ant's Reviews Maybe we are not measuring. We are just arranging them in a 
way that makes sense to us.

If 2 groups are infinitely large, how can one be bigger than the other?

comments.author: apoc29

comments.text:
The Mandelbrot set is a great visual example of how there are infinitely 
many infinities.  There are infinitely many copies of the M-set in the 
whole M-set.  And each of those copies has infinitely many smaller copies 
of the M-set.  And each of those smaller copies has infinitely many even 
smaller copies.  And so on.  There is an infinite regress of copies within 
copies within copies etc.  They are nested within each other infinitely 
many levels deep.  It really boggles the mind.﻿

comments.text:
+Ron Page This is *exactly* what I've been saying about how the marriage of 
Quantum Physics and Classical Physics in a Unified Theory actually works.

+Michio Kaku once explained on a show about how the quantum side says 
infinite infinities repeating while classical physics side of the equation 
says just a single infinity. Unfortunately, he also said the answer was 
nonsense (and erased the board).

But it's *not* nonsense. It's a prime example of the idea that there are 
many infinities and some are bigger than others, while in the quantum side 
we see those infinities at different scales and representing permutations 
of reality. Ergo, a Unified Theory of that nature depends entirely on the 
understanding of Multiverse construct of infinite infinities and 
permutations of scale and circumstance repeating structure like a 
Mandelbrot fractal and also understanding that classical physics is 
confined to a single infinite withing the infinite infinities of 
permutation.

I never understood why Michio Kaku didn't see the answer right in front of 
him if he was able to do the equation...

comments.text:
*Ma quanto è infinito l'Infinito?*

La Matematica di *Cantor* insegna: 
*Vi sono infiniti numeri di infinite grandezze differenti*

[...]
Se questa idea vi rende inquieti, non siete i soli. Alcuni dei più grandi 
matematici del periodo di *Cantor* [1] erano irritati da questa cosa. Non 
comprendendo, provarono a rendere questi differenti infiniti irrilevanti, 
per continuare far lavorar i matematici anche senza di essi.
*Cantor* ne stette talmente male che soffri di una depressione profonda e 
passò l'ultima metà della sua vita dentro e fuori da ospedali psichiatrici.
*Ma alla fine le sue idee vinsero*. 
...
...
*La matematica è considerata a ragione il picco del ragionamento umano*, ma 
adesso, grazie a *Cantor* (e a *Gödel* [2] e *Cohen* [3]) sappiamo che 
anche la Matematica ha dei limiti. Tuttavia, la Matematica ci offre ancora 
cose veramente meravigliose su cui riflettere.
[...]

TED-Ed Original lessons by *Dennis Wildfogel*
► http://ed.ted.com/lessons/how-big-is-infinity

Note:
[1] ►http://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georg_Cantor
[2] ►http://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/G%C3%B6del
[3] ►http://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Cohen﻿

comments.author: Gaurav Rayamajhi

comments.text:
There is no Infinity in the "reality" that we perceive. We confuse Infinity 
with something we could not account for, a really big number. We just call 
that really big number infinite while it is clearly not.
Infinity is an idea of lack of limit. You cannot add to Infinity because 
the Infinite has neither beginning nor ending.
Some mathematicians argue that you can divide something indefinitely, but 
its not possible, for example the fractals, you will eventually stop at the 
iteration X, it will perhaps be a very big number but it is not infinite, 
in other words it is not without limit. However big this X be, its still 
limited.

Lets count all the atoms in this universe, an atom is a limit, we are going 
to start counting from the 1st one and add another and add another and 
another.
Perhaps we are going to reach a number very big, so big that it is 
difficult for us to comprehend but we will never reach Infinity. We will 
get to that last atom.

You cannot get to Infinity by adding limits together.
Our perceptions are based on limits, we cannot perceive that which has no 
limit.
Hypothetically if there were only white color of the same tonality your 
eyes would not  perceive anything since there is no background nor 
foreground. Everything is the same.

The universe we are part of is based on limits, hence it is limited. It is 
undoubtedly VERY BIG but it is still limited.

Now lets take 1 single atom of our universe and make a list of its 
properties of size and mass, its components and its electrical charges and 
all the rules by which this atom is made of. Suppose that we know all that 
there is to know about this atom.

That list would store all the ideas about that atom. Now ideas belong in 
the mind. The mind chooses to think. The mind is the cause and the idea is 
its result.
If the mind chooses to release the idea, that idea would be gone. It would 
no longer exist in the mind.
An idea cannot escape the mind since it is the mind that is thinking that 
idea.

Whatever atoms, or matter, or energy, or simply put, what ever FORM  you 
perceive - is in the mind.
Everything you perceive is part of this mind, perhaps you think that Your 
Mind is in your brain, but your brain is made of atoms and those atoms are 
in some mind.

It is one mind though. All this limited universe is in one mind, being 
thought by one mind. The ideas of this mind share one main property.
They Are Limits.﻿
comments.author: konstantinNeo

comments.author: CuddleNucks

comments.text:
The "bigger infinity" proof on this video is wrong.

Construct a tree-diagram starting with the 10 decimal numbers written to 
one decimal place, each with 10 branches leading to decimal numbers written 
to two decimal places (with the previous decimal place in common with its 
predecessor), each with 10 branches leading to decimal numbers written to 
three decimal places... etc.

For each "layer", all the possible numbers are used up for each decimal 
place so this time no decimals are "left out". Compare this with the same 
tree, but for fractions, and the "proof" in the video no longer works.﻿
comments.author: Nic Digby-Rogers

comments.text:
+Nic Digby-Rogers I don't understand your replay, sorry.

I disagree with your statement that all infinities are equal. Sorry.

But I may show you how maths students may be in the first week of studying 
the topic would use your tree in some imaginary "homework" on this topic:
 
Lets take numbers only from 0 to 1 (it is easy to create one-to-one mapping 
from [0;1] to [-infinity;+infinity]=(Real numbers axe)

The one-to-one mapping that may be created from your tree is:
(Path in the tree) <-->(Real number from 0 to 1).

(for making every path from the "top" to the "bottom" lets asume that for 
instance 0.123=0.1230000...
0.3=0.300000 and so on
 i.e. lets fill in every final decimal fraction with infinitely many zeros)

- How many paths are there?

- From principle of counting the pathes in the finite trees => 10 to some 
power.

- What power is it?
- Countable infinity that is signed by Aleph_0 and Aleph_0 means the number 
of all Natural numbers.

So proved 10^(Aleph_0)=(number of all Real numbers).

And if we take binary representation also kind of strange equality may be 
easily proved:
2^(Aleph_0)=10^(Aleph_0) = by proved with your tree=(Number of real 
numbers).
comments.author: stav03

comments.text:
+stav03 I'm not sure if you're agreeing or disagreeing with me. If you 
construct my tree of decimals and then map it to the same tree structure 
but filled with all the fractions, they each continue forever. That's the 
necessary nature of infinity - neither is bigger than the other. One might 
appear to be getting filled up at a different rate at another, but neither 
tree is ever completely "filled up" because they go on forever.

Therefore one infinite set can't be bigger or smaller than another infinite 
set. Size necessarily requires finite bounds to compare, so how are these 
people who "proved and checked" otherwise smarter? Their answer is 
deductively wrong by definition.

And yes, this is even easier to inductively demonstrate when using binary 
rather than decimal.
comments.author: Nic Digby-Rogers

comments.text:
Nice. If im not wrong you just proved that 10 (or 2 if we allow only binary 
representation for real numbers) to the power of Aleph_0 (the number of 
branches in your tree) is the same as the cardinal number of real numbers 
(sorry, but its bigger infinity, there is nothing to do with it, proved and 
checked by smarter people than we are:)). Also your tree is a good way to 
visualise the continuity (i mean the number of points on the real numbers 
axe) in a "discreet way" (as a number of branches in your infinitely long 
(or high:)) tree.
P.S. Actually making the power of 2 is the standard way to create "the 
bigger infinity" because it means "to count all the subsets". From your 
example follows that you can take any finite basis instead of 2. Again, if 
im not wrong:)
comments.author: stav03

comments.text:
+Ruben Aylwin What does "place" mean when it comes to infinity?
There really is a lot of misunderstanding about infinity going on around 
here.
How far along infinity can anything be? You're trying to deal with finites, 
the exact same error that this video's proof is falling for.
comments.author: Silhouette1984

comments.text:
+Nic Digby-Rogers the problem with your tree is you cant find the infinite 
irrationals, tell me in which place would pi be?
comments.author: Ruben Aylwin

comments.text:
+MuffinsAPlenty If you really can't see past the grid form then my tree 
suggestion can be adapted to an n-dimensional grid. The natural numbers can 
also be written in on the same grid, each with a corresponding element to 
the decimal version. You don't need different numbers of infinities - 
that's just an attempt to make infinity into some kind of number, which 
this video even starts out bebunking. It's no wonder that Godel and Cohen 
correctly contradicted each other, because they were dealing with a 
contradiction.
comments.author: Nic Digby-Rogers

comments.text:
+MuffinsAPlenty Then I am sorry that you fail to see how two different 
trees can be mapped onto one another and revealed to match, much like the 
right onto the left hand or people into seats (the right hand is different 
to the left, and people to seats).
comments.author: Nic Digby-Rogers

comments.text:
The idea of "one-to-one match" is that every element in one set has exactly 
one corresponding element in the other set.

I fail to see how making two different trees satisfies this requirement.
comments.author: MuffinsAPlenty

comments.text:
+MuffinsAPlenty So set out the natural numbers in a tree too. There's 
nothing to say the one-to-one match has to be in 2D grid form.
comments.author: Nic Digby-Rogers

comments.text:
Your tree is not a one-to-one match between the natural numbers and the 
decimal numbers.  At the very best, you'd have 10 decimal numbers matched 
with every natural number.  By its very construction it invalidates itself 
as a counterexample to the proof.
comments.author: MuffinsAPlenty

comments.author: al3ksejkramaric

comments.text:
In some sense it can be applied to real life. Of course there is no 
quantity in real life that is infinitely large but infinity is used to 
calculate real world effects all the time. A simple example would be the 
number pi. It describes the relationship between the diameter and the area 
of a circle. It is impossible to give a decimal that represents the correct 
value of pi but using infinite series you can express the correct value. Of 
course you could never calculate an infinite series but you can approximate 
the actual value to arbitrary precision.
comments.author: compuholic82
